Possibly the most striking evidence of the importance of this view of broad¬
casting is offered by the industry terminology,. They speak of the industry
existing on the basis of "time sales"« The station sells the use of its trans¬
mitter for clock«hours of time at prices which reflect the probability (derived
from audience surveys) that stated numbers of persons will devote the same
dock-hours to attending their receivers,, Negative evidence of the authori¬
tarian implication of broadcasting comes from the absence of capacity for the
viewer or listener to "feed-back" his reactions to the broadcaster. In
designing our broadcast plant the engineers were not called on (as they might
have been) to build into it capacity for "feed-back".
The policy of the business organization which operates our TV and
radio system and motion picture industry is essentially the same as that of
cultural industry^ as a whole. Nor is this surprising, for whether it is
advertiser-supported (as presently is true for TV and radio) or supported by
customer payments (as is true of motion pictures) the same economic considera¬
tions prevail,? Elaborate technology and heavy capital investment in both
cases demand that there be mass production and mass consumption. For this to
happen there must be constant pressure to capture the largest possible audience.
Inevitably homogenization results. A recent and clear statement on this point
comes from Richard S„ Salant, Vice president of Columbia Broadcasting Systems
Inc. I
"What we in the business must remember if we are to survive,
and what our severest critics, iPnot our best friends, push
under their mental rugs, is that network broadcasting serves all
the people*, Unlike a newspaper, it does not have the comfort of
a local or regional audience bound together by the common values
f/ By "cultural industry" I mean the business organization and policy for prod¬
ucing and marketing all consumer goods and services, including the products
and services of the mass media.
